title: Loved it here!
pros: An outstanding company to work for, honestly.
cons: This was a great first company to work for, I had nothing negative to say when I left!

title: Depends on dept.
pros: Concert tickets, some great colleagues
cons: Toxic positivity, policies not enforced for all on team, poor communication on departmental changes , employees don’t turnover who should, was told it was a privilege to receive a laptop and the expectation was to continue to work when I got home, micromanaged…

title: Don't work here if you like a work/life balance
pros: Getting to see great shows.
cons: The Grand Ole Opry still operates like it's 50+ years ago. Half the staff is at retirement age and still drilling old corporate policies that no longer apply today with no interest in new ideas. There is no work/life balance, 50+ hour weeks and still getting work calls on my days off. If you work a 13+ hour show day until 1am you're expected to come into a windowless office the next day for a full 8+ hours instead of resting. There's no work from home policies, and everyone in the office is extremely toxic. The years of bad management and psychology towards one another feeds like a succubus and there's constant finger pointing and snapping instead of solutions. The list goes on, but this company is very good at selling something that isn't true. Worst place I've ever worked at in my entire career. To Collin Reed and all the old men/women in the Ryman hightower, what are you going to do when all the retirement age folks leave, and you can't fill positions because of your outdated policies? You will have a very hard time hiring and will have constant turnover from the younger generations coming in. We are not standing for it, and this is currently happening at the Opry.

title: Better Together
pros:
Great Benefits 
Great Work/home life balance
cons: I have no cons at this time

title: Good days and bad days
pros: You get to work on some cool projects. There is a lot of opportunity for collaboration. There are some good networking opportunities.
cons: You’re never truly “off the clock”. There’s a lack of accountability across the company. When feedback is given to upper management it goes in one ear and out the other. They claim benefits and pay are competitive but they are not.

title: Old school and proud of it
pros: What you see is what you get.
cons: Office and corporate structure are deeply ingrained and even though there are innovative things are happening every day in the office. The strict corporate hierarchy will get in the way.

title: Don’t work here
pros: There are no good reasons
cons: Management is terrible and unhelpful

title: Avoid Corporate
pros: There are some really good people who work here. Projects are fun and some get to work with cool artists. The industry is exciting. The name recognition of OEG sets you up for better jobs down the line. Free shows sometimes. There are a few managers who treat they’re teams with respect. You have opportunities to get as involved as you want to be.
cons: Very corporate atmosphere with an outdated way of thinking that’s negatively effecting employees and our business. Barely any flexibility as far as remote work or scheduling goes. Old school mentality about seniority and promotions: Visibility/Seniority > Good Work. Old CEO calls all the shots even though he’s not CEO anymore. Leadership is reactionary, out of touch, and acts out of fear of old CEO, stakeholders, old audience rather than creating a unified vision or progress. Don’t even get me started on the hollow attempts at celebrating diversity!

title: Great Work Atmosphere
pros: Great Benefits, you feel like your opinion matters, teamwork, and work / life balance is valued. I am happy to be a part of the culture and values this company puts forth!
cons: If you do not like to be valued and treated like a very important member of a team, then this place is NOT for you! Because these are all things you will feel working here. They value your opinion and being a part of a team. They want you to have a healthy work / life balance!

title: Loved Working Here!
pros: The people were amazing and I still keep in touch with some of my coworkers to this day! I also feel like was compensated fairly for the role.
cons: I personally didn't love some of the practices that my boss partook in, but I know he's no longer with the company, and the new boss is amazing!

title: Amazing company to work for. Really hold every employee to a high value.
pros: Amazing culture, great perks, great pay. Work/life balance is a real priority.
cons: Growing extremely fast to care about the little things. But all is well regardless.

title: Truly Cares about Employees
pros: Actual work/life balance, flexible, understanding of life outside work, supportive in work and life, excellent "perks", great office location, slower pace than most companies.
cons: A bit chaotic with a multitude of systems that do relatively the same thing, documentation/SOP is lacking, small teams for areas that need the most work (can be a pro and a con), inconsistencies, many business processes not set up properly which then have work arounds in place by support teams, employees not made aware of the "bigger picture" and long term plans.

title: Great Company
pros: Family oriented, competitive pay, flexible hours.
cons: I have no personal cons to list.

title: Solid Place to Work
pros: Fun industry, iconic brands and good people
cons: Somewhat stuffy at corporate. There is a pretty visible hierarchy and being heard in any meaningful ways is going to be hard.

title: Did Not Love The Change
pros: Insurance Benefits Employee Benefits Discounts Retirement Plans
cons: Cashed out at the end of the shift Made promises that were not met Taxed heavily on bonuses Did not treat employees fairly

title: Great place to work
pros: Amazing people plus you get to see the shows.
cons: Have to work on Saturdays.

title: Great company!
pros: It was a great place to work! Nice people and healthy environment.
cons: I worked in a cubicle which I did not like

title: Not provided
pros: Good people and fun environment
cons: Seasanol work volume was inconsistent

title: Love working for RHP
pros: RHP is a fantastic place to work. The care, attention, and support of the HR team/upper management to their employees doesn't go unnoticed. They are quick to remedy uneasy situations and look for ways to best accommodate their employees in any given situation. RHP goes above and beyond to make work a place to love to come to (even in a corporate environment) by working hard to create a sense of community amongst its employees.
cons: Sometimes a disconnect between departments. Sometimes a lack of knowing how work flows in working with other departments. Good perks but would love to have the opportunity to buy venue (Ryman, Opry, etc...) tickets at a discount other than service fees.

title: Great company!
pros: RHP is a great company to work for because it's like a family.
cons: It can be difficult to climb the ladder unless you can get a job in management.

title: Ryman Auditorium
pros: Easy job with benefits, free shows
cons: Low pay, especially for downtown

title: Amazing Company
pros: This company really cares about their culture and their employees. It is a fun place to work and everyone is very helpful and nice! Great training programs that are available for all employees and really help if you want to move up within the organization. There are a lot of opportunities for growth!
cons: None, I enjoy my job and the people I work with!

title: Should have taken these other reviews as warning. Single parents, listen up.
pros: The wonderful history within the Ryman and the Grand Ole Opry. Saying that you work for either of them always garners impressive comments from others. But that don't pay the bills. Pay is okay, but not for the amount of unneeded stress you'll endure.
cons: HR department is terrified of communicating with anyone who's not "top-floor". Highly tout "hybrid, flexible workplace" when interviewing, but please don't be fooled. You'll get one day WFH/week at best, and they make you feel bad about it. The corporate office is more cliquey and catty than a teen movie. The amount of bickering that goes on between leadership roles over the dumbest projects and deadlines is laughable. If they'd spend half of the energy expended on that (or the inane team-building exercises you're forced to endure) lord knows what kind of heights this company would be taken to... And it's not like the company is doing terribly - they're rich as balls and like to tell you about it, as if it's also in your bank account as well. "Hey everybody, come see how good I look!" As I said, single parents - listen up. I'm a single father of 2 very young children, and from the day that I was hired, I was up-front in communicating that I needed to make full use of their so-called flex-time and remote policies, as there are times where I have no control over what time I need to leave the office in order to pick up my kids on-time. I was CONSTANTLY bullied by my direct supervisor over this, requesting that I submit my arrival/departure schedule to her WEEKLY for approval, though it never changed. Well, that wasn't going to happen. I was terminated because of this, and it's wrong on so many levels. Mental health is not a concern for leadership or HR. If you disclose you have a problem and need help, they will single you out. Also, get ready for all of the most cliché meme-worthy moments possible in a corporate setting. Pizza parties to celebrate record earnings in Q1! Teambuilding exercises at an escape room. All the gaslighting you can take. Take heed and go elsewhere. This place doesn't have the legacy of any of these historic brands they manage in mind, just how much they can earn. I get it, we're all in business for money, but take care of your people. Lastly - Diversity & Inclusion is touted as a top priority in this organization, but it's laughable. It all comes down to making sure there's a token person of color in all marketing materials, that's about it.

title: Be Ready To Burn Out
pros: Friendships, Ryman staff, experiences, exciting projects, national recognition in terms of venues for resume building
cons: No work-life balance, great employees burn out quickly, frequent restructuring, completely out of touch leadership Corporate leadership is out of touch with their employees and industry standards, and continues to hire executives with no prior music industry experience. I spent many hours explaining to VP level employees how marketing within the concert industry works, which as a professional who would still like to learn, was defeating. The workload assigned and expected from corporate marketing is unmanageable, and when you do express being overwhelmed you'll be told to suck it up. Don't let the shiny factor of the experiences distract you from very toxic culture present. It is not worth it. If you try to defend yourself, you'll be told you're not a "team player." You can do better and deserve to be treated better. You'll have to defend your work each day as your leader won't. Nothing is ever good enough, and then there's the verbal abuse from higher level employees that no one seems to find unacceptable.

title: I Wouldn’t
pros: Ryman Auditorium’s management and staff
cons: Ryman Auditorium’s management, the c-suite corporate directors, and Colin Reed

title: Terrible HR
pros: Used to be a fun place to work
cons: I had a problem with a fellow employee. I reported it to HR and not only did they lie to me but they never did anything about my problem. HR only told me what they thought I wanted to hear. DONT TRUST THEM AND DONT BELIEVE THEM. They have made the Ryman a terrible place to work

title: Don’t waste your time
pros: Amazing history in buildings, chance to meet many interesting people
cons: Upper management couldn’t care less about employees

title: Disappointing
pros: Incredible employees who are all passionate about the history and the music of the Grand Ole Opry
cons: Toxic work environment, management lacks leadership, very little care of keeping good employees

title: Ok Place with a Lot of Problems
pros: Venues are well known and loved in the area; Opportunity to see shows and work events that you wouldn't get at your typical 9-5 job; Casual dress; Lots of growth on the horizon if people can pull a decent plan together
cons: Employees are ruled over from the 4th floor by all white males; Diversity council is disingenuous; Management lacks any real ownership or interest in process improvement; No clear vision of the future; Benefits are meh; No parental leave

title: Great Place To Work
pros: All of the employees that work for Ryman are fantastic, everyone at the Opry House, Ryman Auditorium and Grand Ole Opry show are all great people to work with and really care. The family atmosphere is completely apparent throughout the employee culture.
cons: For most part-time employees, there are slow parts of the year when there isn't much work at the Opry. That's just something you need to be aware of, that your income will probably suffer throughout the winter months, or you will need to work in different positions.

title: Lots of weaknesses
pros: Many employees are passionate about the hospitality/music industry and the history of the organization, especially those working directly with guests. It's a great thing to see.
cons: Some managers lack leadership skills, creating confusion around office structure and project delegation. You often feel like you're spread too thin and aren't supported, which causes stress. The company operates on a feast-or-famine mentality. It's willing to spend on big projects that could be better researched beforehand while employees don't have access to proper tools to maximize efficiency. Wages aren't as competitive as you'd expect to see unless you hold a C-Suite job title. Work/life balance is hard to achieve, and those who attempt to establish boundaries are shamed for not being a "team player." Bad behavior, like lying and belittling other employees, is hardly ever reprimanded.

title: Unfair treatment if you have any emotions.
pros: Good pay ($10/hr) Decent hours, three days minimum a week. Amazing shows, you literally get paid to watch a show. Opportunities to meet artists (or at least see them). Discounts at the cafe and gift shops and places downtown, and Disneyland!
cons: Lazy supervisors that don't know when to do their jobs. No decent breaks, you are given 10 minutes even if you work eight hours. Very strict about breaks even if you need to deal with something. Bad commute if you don't live in Nashville. Unfair treatment if you aren't stern, stone faced, and if you show any heart or sympathy to people.

title: The most incredible company + work environment!
pros: We are paid well, there is an incredible work + company culture environment, and I truly feel cared for by my coworkers and upper management. Character, work ethic, and culture fit are at the forefront of hiring and it shows. Everyone at Circle is actively aware + vocal about how lucky we are to genuinely like each other and our work. Not to mention the perks!! If you want to grow your career in the music/ entertainment business you couldn't work at a better place, truly there are so many opportunities for great genuine connections. Truly a great company to work for, I recommend it to everyone I know looking for jobs in the Nashville entertainment/ music business.
cons: none to share at this time

title: The Peter Principle At Work
pros: The company has some great benefits for full-time team members (health, dental, + vision with a very reasonable employee contribution, a 401k with a 4% match vested immediately) and they rely very heavily on their long-standing reputation as meccas within the entertainment industry. They talk all the time about how cool it is to work there because of the Ryman Auditorium and the Grand Ole Opry, and depending on your role, you will get to interface with some great music business connections, as well as go to some fun destinations along with the hotel properties they own and new Ole Red restaurant chain. If you work in the corporate building, you have access to some perks such as $4 lunch in the cafeteria on Tuesdays and Thursdays, a gym, Crossfit and Yoga classes, and if you are at a certain level within the company, you can request tickets in the suite at Bridgestone Arena for concerts, events, and Predators games.
cons: The company has an internal identity that is completely at odds with the actual working experience. HR and C-Suite level team members talk all the time about the great culture and how cool it is to work there, but the culture is very condescending, mainly held as a standard for front line and hourly employees while salaried and senior leaders are not held equally accountable and are not well versed in the culture themselves. The culture on paper looks good at first glance, but upon a little closer observation, you realize it's just leftovers from the days when the company operated the hotel, and most leaders couldn't tell you the Vision Statement if their life depended on it, let alone the other components of the aspirational, cartoony fluff being passed off as core to the company's values. Speaking of Salaried and Hourly Employees... the pay is good if you are an exempt team member, but if you are hourly you have to fight for every cent you have. There is no consistent policy for team outings (birthday lunches- am I expected to participate as a volunteer or stay on the clock?), and in general the pay is less than what you can make elsewhere in Nashville. There are lots of leaders that are holdovers from the Gaylord days, and many of them have risen to a level in the organization that is completely beyond their capabilities and skillsets. As a result, many of these mid- to high level leaders work constantly (several of my leaders have sent me emails at 3am and no, they aren't working the entertainment shows on these nights) in order to try to outpace their inadequacy and inability to delegate properly. There is a culture that you have to give everything to work, which would be one thing if people worked well together. On the contrary, the organization is extremely disconnected, with each team operating as its own silo, and communication is abysmal, with lots of duplicate work because the culture does not encourage sharing of resources and knowledge. There is no regular feedback process for team members to go through to voice concerns and frustrations other than going directly to HR, who rarely make an effort to correct the situation. The only real time an employee can voluntarily voice feedback is when leaving the company, and then the HR team discounts the perspectives as disgruntled employees. When feedback is done, it is in the form of handpicking team members to talk to the CEO so that he gets a very sanitized view of the perception within the organization. Voluntary development tools are also lacking; leaders are expected to attend mandatory training periodically, but there is no accountability if a leader decides not to participate. They only offer tuition reimbursement on college degree programs, so if you want to get a certificate or other training that would positively impact your abilities in your role, it is dependent on if your leader is willing to part with a few dollars from their budget (precious few leaders see the value in this). Most disturbing is the fact that all the C-suite leaders have surrounded themselves with yes men. Anytime an executive changes direction or priority, the whole team is expected to jump up and immediately get to work on the passion project du jour. The leaders can get ugly and aggressive in meetings and lash out at team members, but there is no culture of open dialogue and feedback, so rather than having a heated but open conversation on the goals and direction of strategy, mid-level leaders kowtow to this behavior, come back to their teams, and have truly unreasonable expectations for the team members to then meet these new deadlines and project achievements. There is no solid priority set for the future, so the minute a C-suite leader makes an offhanded comment about one area, everyone jumps to make a difference in that business area (think of rats skittering from side to side on a ship). This means that when new leadership is brought in, the selection process is very short sited or expectations are grandiose (we've had 3 new CMOs in 2 years, and multiple people are starting to count on 2 hands the number of bosses they've reported to in the same time period). Some leaders overstep their bounds to assert their dominance on areas of the business they shouldn't be involved in; meanwhile, other leaders don't hold their team accountable.

title: They can Do Better (So Can You)
pros: The leadership specifically at the Ryman is amazing! I had the opportunity to work alongside some of the most talented and passionate employees. Benefits are good. Managers at the Ryman seem to actually care about the success of their employees. If you let your leaders know you're interested in learning new things, in my experience, they'll teach you what you want to know. Lots of good music and great history! A fun environment at the Ryman.
cons: The pay is NOT competitive, at least not for non-exempt employees. As a whole, this company loves a good restructure. It happened multiple times during my years with the company. Often times, the restructures were not well thought out and caused more issues than anything, which eventually lead to more restructuring. Depending on the position, there isn't a great work-life balance. Corporate is very political. The Opry will always be the "golden child". As a whole, the company will talk about all the growth potential, but realistically, the opportunities for promotions are few and far between. Corporate has a condescending attitude and those in management positions will lie and take credit for your work in order to protect themselves. Annual raises are a joke.

title: Good place to gain some experience
pros: You will work next to some awesome people, and gain great work experience that will help you get another job. Some cool perks like ocasional free Opry show tickets, and back stage tour tickets, $4. Lunches on Tuesday and Thursday. Small onsite gym, and CrossFit classes. They are in the process of renovating the corporate office so offices will be NICE! The people you work next to every day are helpful and friendly. You can dress pretty casual everyday.
cons: They just laid some people off on the marketing team so not much job stability. High Turn over rate. Hard to move up in the company. Not a lot of flexibility as far as hours go. Work 9-6

title: Slow growth
pros: Co-workers and legendary history of venues are great and make work enjoyable.
cons: Growth comes slowly - people stay a long time (decades) and are promised growth for hard work - and somehow the promised growth never comes into fruition.

title: Dream Job Turned Nightmare
pros: Decent health benefits, 401 k (match up to 4%), PTO accrual, options to attend shows that are not selling well.
cons: I do not recommend this place to anyone. In fact, at this point I feel major guilt when we interview/hire amazing candidates because I know their talents are going to be wasted coming in here. RHP claims to want to be hiring "experts in their fields" but really they only want yes-men that will jump when C-Suite (or the select few individuals that hold tremendous amounts of power) says “jump”. Between constantly sticking up for your work (your manager/director will not) through a spider web of red-tape and approvals, and the horrendous work-life balance you will quickly burn-out. But that's okay! There are members of C-Suite that have been on record saying they want younger employees that they can pay less and work harder. Unfortunately, that's probably why we are sitting at a 50%+ turnover rate. Many members of my team (and I know to be true of other departments in the organization) have attempted to go to their leaders and tell them that things are not working, and we need to come together and find ways to fix things or we are going to see a lot of people leave. These conversations are all met the same way with harsh defenses and "your feelings are incorrect". Feedback given to the HR team is swept under the rug. Everyone just wants C-Suite to think everything is okay. It's not okay. The ship is sinking. Get out the violins.

title: Fun Job
pros: If you like working security and have an interest in the music industry, then this is a great place for you. If you are competent and perform at a level higher than your peers then you will be put in positions of greater responsibility among the big names of the entertainment industry.
cons: Pay is not competitive considering responsibilities or against other security positions in Nashville

title: Antiquated at best, Regressive at worst
pros: Great benefits including $4 lunches on Tuesdays and Thursdays, comprehensive healthcare plans, cross fit and yoga if desired on certain days and Rally Rewards with up to $200 gift cards if you participate. Occasionally, we have a farmers market that showcases local produce and vendors.
cons: This company suffers from poor leadership from the top down. The CEO surrounds himself with "yes men" who reinforce his outlook and priorities. At one point, one of our weaker business ventures had been poorly performing for months and the CEO became aware of this last, mostly due to no one telling him about the failure. Other C-suites remain out of touch regarding day to day tasks and responsibilities of their team but remain mercurial. When they do decide to jump in and work with the team, they cause more confusion in their effort to catch up on the business. When it becomes apparent that the leadership is out of the loop, has not read emails, etc, they become defensive or act out. Poor leadership at this company has created a company culture where employees (who are trained adults and experts in their fields) have zero autonomy or authority in their work --- everything is second guessed after the fact and minute details that don't jive with the absent c-suites are deemed as "big misses" and projects grind to a screeching halt over elements that are not business impacting or revenue driving. This company does not reinvest in their employees encouraging additional training, certificates, conferences, etc. Many employees at Managerial levels have simply stayed with the company for a decade (sometimes starting on the Hotel side) and have been systematically promoted/rewarded regardless of their competence or skill set that best suits the role. Perhaps most alarming, feedback given to HR is met with blank stares as if a robot received a programming error. Recently, the company decided to offer vacation accrual (because prior, no vacation was offered for an employee's first year). HR presented this change like some grand innovation when really, this is the bare minimum offered by companies country-wide. It's like someone getting the iPhone 3 and being really impressed with the new technology and having no clue that they're 7 generations behind. Another contradiction, the company maintains that they are the leader in entertainment and want to remain competitive in the space. Everyone I have spoken to at this company has admitted they took a significant pay cut to work for RHP. This is concerning considering the CEO gets a significant bonus (rumored to be in the millions) every year.

title: Be Careful!
pros: - The people, all of the employees not beholden to the corporate structure are incredible people. - The benefits. If you happen to find a way into one of the minimally available full time positions the benefits are fantastic.
cons: You know how people joke about evil corporations? Ryman HP may just be the example to take a look at. They have a stranglehold on the hospitality industry in the Nashville area so wages are stagnant. They tend to lead their most hopeful employees on with a carrot on a stick when it comes to moving up-- they talk up their "growth potential", but there aren't the positions available anywhere within. How is it that a company so proud to reach the coveted title of "Billion dollar company" has so many elderly employees working for 8.25/hr, some of which have worked there for 47 years, that have never received a raise? They keep their non-corporate management in the dark which leads to confusion throughout all of the departments. Communication in general between departments is lacking. The non-corporate management dictated by the uncaring, unseen, arcane corporate side neglects being direct in instruction in order to perpetuate the faux family atmosphere of the staff. The staff themselves live up to these standards of family, but the management continually makes new and confusing policies that do the exact opposite. Company propaganda has recently been pushed through that at the very least asks the employees to memorize and recite the company motto, and they go as far as to ask employees to attend wellness fairs with health screenings-- that basically hands over their personal information to the company to use how they see fit. Pay is horrendous. Even after a small raise I was still well under the reasonable living wage in my area. The management above me was not fairing much better as well as the management above them. No one there is satisfied with what they are paid. Where is the money going? Meanwhile the CEO, gave himself a bonus in the higher end of six figures while his lowest level employees are working for poverty wages. There are more than one employees who are sexually harassing other employees, as well as guests, who have yet to be reprimanded or let go. One employee, who was gender non-conforming, only discussing it through their personal social media , was even shamed into leaving the company by other employees without anyone in management addressing the bullying. This was not an isolated incident. Don't be fooled by the faux positivity and friendly atmosphere, the closer you look the more sour it will become.

title: Decent company
pros: Benefits are good and they always try to do right by employees
cons: Leadership is a bit stale and has antiquated ways of thinking. Most positions at the corporate level could be work-from-home but top leaders still want people physically in the building.

title: Don't do it
pros: Inconsistent perks, but when they were available they were great. Excellent health insurance.
cons: Poor leadership at all levels. Toxic culture where burn out is rewarded. Diversity initiatives are transactional, not genuine, not working and developed by the majority male, majority white corporate leadership team.

title: Treat employees better before they leave
pros: One of the most well-known companies in Nashville
cons: - Salary increase cap - Unnecessary time off blackout dates around the holidays - Not upholding their own values

title: Fun place to work they just don't pay well.
pros: Fun place to work you get to watch concerts while you work. Other benefits including discounts on some shows and Nissan vehicles.
cons: Low pay is the biggest concern with the job. High turn over rate due to the low pay.

title: Tour Guide
pros: Good co-workers Flexible hours Tour guests can be fun
cons: Pay is not great for this high energy job schedule can change suddenly heavy lifting and carrying is involved to prepare for tours

title: Great Place to Work
pros: The team is dynamic. The companies legacy speaks for itself. Our candidate pool is well activated and our employees are proud to work here.
cons: RHP corporate operates as a well oiled machine and it requires a steep learning curve.

title: Be Careful
pros: Good way to get experience to work elsewhere Shows are fun Lots of great people to meet beyond leaders
cons: Toxic workaholic culture Constant shuffling of upper level executives Takes advantage of young talent Long hours with little flexibility

title: Working in the Museum
pros: Working with awesome people and awesome bosses, being part of legendary history where music all began in Nashville, fun work environment
cons: Upper management treats you like an inferior, low pay, horrible parking situation, very little opportunities for growth

title: Great, historical part-time job
pros: -Working in a beautiful building with a great time
cons: -Pay could be better and upper management could have bit more transparency

title: Good Part Time Job, but Poor Pay
pros: Nice work environment with fun people. Easy work. If you are a student this works well around classes.
cons: Poor pay and it doesn't increase much. They are only semi flexible if your schedule changes.

title: Solid Gig
pros: Great benefits, good culture and fun working environment
cons: Pay was comparably weaker than other companies in the industry

title: Ok Corporate culture seems a bit toxic
pros: Tickets to shows. Discounts on merch.
cons: Corporate acts like they care but do not back it up with wages

title: A great experience
pros: A great venue, awesome people to work with
cons: the pay and mobility to move up could be better

title: Great!
pros: One of the best reasons to work for Ryman Hospitality Properties (REIT) is the professional, fun working environment that is present.
cons: Increased technology capabilities and flexible work schedules for corporate employees.

title: Bartender
pros: It is a tight knit group of employees at the location I work.
cons: Seniority takes over on busy shows which may affect how much you make per night.

title: Operations
pros: Great place to work, great culture, great people!
cons: Irregular hours depending on events.

title: The company is undergoing significant change
pros:
Chance to rebuild things properly
Smaller teams
cons:
Poor moral
Uncertain future
Lack of resources

title: Retail
pros: Fast Paced Always meeting new people Great Hours (usually 9-5:30 or show hours 5-11) Amazing management and team
cons: Pay was okay. Nothing great. Barely above minimum

title: Great company!
pros: Cares about employees, continued to pay us through the shutdown. Very professional company.
cons: Not enough hours at times.

title: Former retail sales associate
pros: amazing people, great customers, my manager was very flexible and nice
cons: some location's management was rude and unprofessional

title: strong growth opportunities
pros: ryman leadership, work/life balance, pay
cons: inconsistencies from corporate, lack of clear direction from corporate

title: Fantastic Work Environment
pros: Great People, Great Company Culture,
cons: I did not have any cons while working here,

title: Great first job while going through school.
pros: Flexibility in schedule, fun atmosphere, great for side gig
cons: None that are worth mentioning.

title: Love working here
pros: Great team, great working environment
cons: My current supervisor likes his team to be in the office every day.

title: Growing
pros: fun coworkers, peek in at the shows
cons: no set schedule open everyday except Thanksgiving = so no work-life balance usually understaffed

title: Great easy job
pros: Easy job with not very much trouble
cons: Can be boring at times if you’re not working shows

title: Hostess
pros: Awesome community culture of family for environment
